Award.AwardTitle: Longitudinal Study of Astronomy Graduate Students
Award.AbstractNarration: Past snapshots of the fraction of professional astronomers who are women at various career stages have suggested a higher attrition rate than for men. While anecdotal evidence suggests possible reasons, reliable statistical data and analyses are lacking. This award will enable the PI to follow a cohort of men and women astronomers over a decade, track the decisions they make, and make links to underlying causes. The time period is key to success, collecting data from the cohort in three staged surveys. The award will support the analysis of data from the second survey round, the preparation of the third survey and its analysis, and linking together the ultimate findings and conclusions from the complete program. Using data from all three rounds, the Longitudinal Study will ultimately: (1) provide detailed data on trends in employment over 10+ years for a single cohort, (2) collect data on people who leave the field of astronomy during or after graduate school, (3) determine whether there are sex differences in attrition from astronomy and reasons for this, and (4) examine factors that precede decisions to persist in, or leave, the field of astronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The Longitudinal Study of Astronomy Graduate Students provided data about trends in astronomy employment that were previously unavailable. The goals were to: 

  • Provide detailed data on trends in employment over 10+ years for a single cohort of astronomy graduate students
  • Collect data on people who leave the field of astronomy during or after graduate school
  • Determine whether there are sex differences in attrition from astronomy and reasons for this, and
  • Examine factors that precede decisions to persist in, or leave, the field of astronomy.

We accomplished this by collecting data from a single cohort of graduate students in astronomy and astrophysics during 2006-07. We collected data from this same group of students at three different points: a) 2007-08, b) 2012-13, and c) 2015-16. At the conclusion of the study, about 30% of the people who had earned PhDs and were not in postdoctoral positions were no longer working in the fields of astronomy and physics. One of the best predictors of working in the field long-term was taking a postdoctoral appointment. In addition, our results showed that people who leave the field are unlikely to return.

One of the main emphases of the study was to look at gender differences in working in or out of astronomy and physics. We found that gender did not directly affect working out of the field after earning a PhD. In other words, women were not more likely than men to leave the field just because of their gender. Instead, we found that graduate students' relationships with their dissertation advisors have long-term effects on working in or out of the field. If the graduates reported less than satisfactory relationships with their advisors, they were more likely to leave the field. In addition, the difficulties that astronomers can face in locating two jobs--one for themselves and one for their partner--in the same geographic area can lead to attrition from the field. This problem, often called the "two-body" problem, is reported more often by women in this study, and women are also more likely than men to report less than satisfactory relationships with their advisors.  

 

Broader Impacts:

The results of this study will allow the astronomy and astrophysics community to implement data-based policies and programs that can lead to increased retention in the field. According to our results, one of the main issues that can improve retention is improving the relationships that graduate students have with their dissertation advisors. This will also have the additional benefit of improving the graduate education experience for all students.

The project identifies factors that lead to attrition and also shows that women experience these factors more often than men. If policy makers and administrators implement steps to ameliorate these issues, the result could ultimately be increased participation of women in astronomy and astrophysics.

In addition to documenting the long-term effects of the dissertation advisor on retention in the field, this study found that the two-body problem also contributes to attrition from the field. This problem may be difficult to address, but anecdotal information shows us that universities are aware of this problem and, in some cases, take steps to address it.

The respondents in this project were all originally graduate students in astronomy and astrophysics. Nevertheless, the results can have implications for related fields, such as physics and mathematics, both of which are related substantively to astronomy, and, in the case of mathematics, has similar representation of women. Preparing science and mathematics students for diverse careers and retaining them in fields related to their graduate training will also produce a larger and more diverse scientific and technically trained workforce, thus increasing national competitiveness.
